docs.text: weighed down by tired plot lines and spielberg's reliance on formulas , _saving private ryan_ is a mediocre film which nods in the direction of realism before descending into an abyss of cliches .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there ought to be a law against steven spielberg making movies about truly serious topics .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: spielberg's greatest strength as a director is the polished , formulaic way in which every aspect of the film falls carefully into place to make a perfect story .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but for a topic of such weight as combat in the second world war ( or the holocaust ) this technique backfires , for it creates coherent , comprehensible and redemptive narratives out of events whose size , complexity and evil are utterly beyond the reach of human ken .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: in this way spielberg trivializes the awesome evil of the stories he films .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: _saving private ryan_ tells the story of eight men who have been detailed on a " pr mission " to pull a young man , ryan ( whose three other brothers were just killed in fighting elsewhere ) out of combat on the normandy front just after d-day .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: ryan is a paratrooper who dropped behind enemy lines the night before the landings and became separated from his fellow soldiers .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the search for him takes the eight soldiers across the hellish terrain of world war ii combat in france .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there's no denying spielberg came within shouting distance of making a great war movie .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the equipment , uniforms and weapons are superbly done .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the opening sequence , in which captain miller ( tom hanks ) leads his men onto omaha beach , is quite possibly the closest anyone has come to actually capturing the unendurably savage intensity of modern infantry combat .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: another pleasing aspect of the film is spielberg's brave depiction of scenes largely unknown to american audiences , such as the shooting of prisoners by allied soldiers , the banality of death in combat , the routine foul-ups in the execution of the war , and the cynicism of the troops .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the technical side of the film is peerless , as always .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the camera work is magnificent , the pacing perfect , the sets convincing , the directing without flaw .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: hanks will no doubt be nominated for an oscar for his performance , which was utterly convincing , and the supporting cast was excellent , though ted danson seems a mite out of place as a paratroop colonel .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: yet the attempt at a realistic depiction of combat falls flat on its face because realism is not something which can be represented by single instances or events .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: it has to thoroughly permeate the context at every level of the film , or the story fails to convince .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: throughout the movie spielberg repeatedly showed only single examples of the grotesque wounds produced by modern mechanized devices ( exception : men are shown burning to death with relative frequency ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: for example , we see only one man with guts spilled out on the ground .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: here and there men lose limbs ; in one scene miller is pulling a man to safety , there's an explosion , and miller looks back to see he is only pulling half a man .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: but the rest of the corpses are remarkably intact .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: there are no shoes with only feet in them , no limbs scattered everywhere , no torsos without limbs , no charred corpses , and most importantly , all corpses have heads ( in fairness there are a smattering of wicked head wounds ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the relentless dehumanization of the war , in which even corpses failed to retain any indentity , is soft-pedaled in the film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: ultimately , _saving private ryan_ bows to both hollywood convention and the unwritten rules of wartime photography in its portrayal of wounds and death in war .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: rather than saying _saving private ryan_ is " realistic , " it would be better to describe it as " having realistic moments . "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: another aspect of the " hollywoodization " of the war is the lack of realistic dialogue and in particular , the lack of swearing .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: anyone familiar with the literature on the behavior of the men during the war , such as fussell's superb _wartime : understanding and behavior in the second world war_ ( which has an extensive discussion on swearing ) , knows that the troops swore fluently and without letup .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: " who is this private ryan that we have to die for him ? "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: asks one infantrymen in the group of eight .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: rendered in wartime demotic , that should have been expressed as " who is this little pecker that we have to get our dicks shot off for him ? "
docs.label: negative

docs.text: or some variant thereof .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: conversations should have been literally sprinkled with the " f " word , and largely about ( the search for ) food and sex .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: this is all the more inexplicable because the movie already had an " r " rating due to violence , so swearing could not possibly have been eliminated to make it a family film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: however , the most troubling aspect of the film is the spielbergization of the topic .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: the most intense hell humans have ever created for themselves is not emotionally wrenching enough for steven spielberg .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: he cannot just cede control to the material ; he has to be bigger than it .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: as if afraid to let the viewer find their own ( perhaps unsettled and not entirely clear ) emotional foothold in the material , spielberg has to package it in hallmark moments to give the war a meaning and coherence it never had : the opening and closing scenes of ryan and his family in the war cemetary ( reminscent of the closing scene from _schindler's list ) , the saccharine exchange between ryan and his wife at the close ( every bit as bad as schindler's monologue about how his car , tiepin or ring could have saved another jew ) , quotes from abraham lincoln and emerson , captain miller's last words to private ryan , and an unbelievable storyline in which a prisoner whom they free earlier in the movie comes back to kill the captain .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: that particular subplot is so hokey , so predictable , it nigh on ruins the film .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: nowhere in the film is there a resolute depiction of the meaninglessness , stupidity and waste which characterized the experience of war to the men who actually fought in combat ( imagine if miller had been killed by friendly fire or collateral damage ) .
docs.label: negative

docs.text: because of its failure to mine deeply into the terrible realities of world war ii , _saving private ryan_ can only pan for small truths in the shallows .
docs.label: negative
